articles.headline: Wall Street Scion Is Accused of Faking Investments
articles.snippet: The $95 million scheme highlights how much research and checking institutional investors actually do when making an investment.
articles.abstract: The $95 million scheme highlights how much research and checking institutional investors actually do when making an investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: A 39-year-old Wall Street executive, Andrew Caspersen came from a life of privilege and opportunity: Groton, Princeton and then Harvard Law School, where the student center is named after his family because of a generous gift from his father.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Automakers Expanding in China May Soon Face Weakening Demand
articles.snippet: China is the world’s largest market for new cars, but its slowing economy could leave automakers with too many factories and not enough buyers.
articles.abstract: China is the world’s largest market for new cars, but its slowing economy could leave automakers with too many factories and not enough buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The new $1.3 billion Cadillac factory on the outskirts of Shanghai is a shrine to modern manufacturing, the kind of facility that automakers all over the world dream of building but can seldom afford.

articles.headline: U.S. Says It Has Unlocked iPhone Without Apple
articles.snippet: The Justice Department announcement, in a court filing, ends an immediate legal battle over the San Bernardino shooting case but raises questions about Apple’s security.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department announcement, in a court filing, ends an immediate legal battle over the San Bernardino shooting case but raises questions about Apple’s security.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Justice Department said on Monday that it had found a way to unlock an iPhone without help from Apple, allowing the agency to withdraw its legal effort to compel the tech company to assist in a mass-shooting investigation.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Pandora Replaces Chief, Aiming to Reinvent Itself Midstream
articles.snippet: Tim Westergren, a co-founder of Pandora, becomes chief executive as the online music company tries to regain its competitive edge.
articles.abstract: Tim Westergren, a co-founder of Pandora, becomes chief executive as the online music company tries to regain its competitive edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pandora Media became a powerhouse in online music primarily by doing one thing: tailoring song after song to the tastes of its listeners, along with the occasional ad. For a decade, it worked well, as Pandora came to dominate Internet radio.

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Success Upends Battle for Control of Congress
articles.snippet: Republican lawmakers are trying to distance themselves from Mr. Trump, while Democrats seize on the chance to run against a candidate who has offended huge sections of the electorate.
articles.abstract: Republican lawmakers are trying to distance themselves from Mr. Trump, while Democrats seize on the chance to run against a candidate who has offended huge sections of the electorate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s dominance in the Republican primary is upending the campaign for control of Congress, as Republican lawmakers seek to distance themselves from him while Democrats seize on the chance to run against a candidate who has offended huge sections of the American electorate.

articles.headline: ValueAct Pays a Price for Its Supporting Role at Valeant
articles.snippet: ValueAct deserves credit — or blame — for virtually everything that happened to Valeant Pharmaceuticals over nearly the last decade.
articles.abstract: ValueAct deserves credit — or blame — for virtually everything that happened to Valeant Pharmaceuticals over nearly the last decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Ackman gets a lot of ink and a lot of criticism as one of the largest investors behind the crisis-ridden Valeant Pharmaceuticals.

articles.headline: $15-an-Hour Minimum Wage in California? Plan Has Some Worried
articles.snippet: The move to raise the statewide minimum wage would make California a guinea pig in a bold economic experiment.
articles.abstract: The move to raise the statewide minimum wage would make California a guinea pig in a bold economic experiment.
articles.lead_paragraph: California is on the verge of making itself a guinea pig in a bold economics experiment.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Ian Lovett

articles.headline: In Apple Debate on Digital Privacy and the iPhone, Questions Still Remain
articles.snippet: It is unclear what will happen the next time the government tries to force Apple to break into one of its own phones.
articles.abstract: It is unclear what will happen the next time the government tries to force Apple to break into one of its own phones.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A furious legal battle over digital privacy in the age of the iPhone ended on Monday with no clear winner — only lingering questions over what will happen the next time the government tries to force Apple to help break into one of its own phones.

articles.headline: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
articles.snippet: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
articles.abstract: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The day he left Syria with instructions to carry out a terrorist attack in France, Reda Hame, a 29-year-old computer technician from Paris, had been a member of the Islamic State for just over a week.

articles.headline: No One Hurt as EgyptAir Flight Is Forced to Cyprus in a Hijacking From the Heart
articles.snippet: A man claiming to wear an explosive vest forced an EgyptAir plane to land in Cyprus before he was arrested. He had issued an incoherent set of demands, and wanted to see his ex-wife.
articles.abstract: A man claiming to wear an explosive vest forced an EgyptAir plane to land in Cyprus before he was arrested. He had issued an incoherent set of demands, and wanted to see his ex-wife.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Getting out of Egypt was never going to be easy for Seif Eldin Mustafa, a fugitive Egyptian convict who has been on the run since he escaped from prison five years ago. But on Tuesday, he resorted to extraordinary measures.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Nour Youssef

articles.headline: Nafta May Have Saved Many Autoworkers’ Jobs
articles.snippet: There is a good case to be made that without Nafta, there might not be much left of Detroit at all. A wall of tariffs against Mexico would probably do more harm than good.
articles.abstract: There is a good case to be made that without Nafta, there might not be much left of Detroit at all. A wall of tariffs against Mexico would probably do more harm than good.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump threatened to “break” the North American Free Trade Agreement, auto industry workers offered up some of the loudest cheers.

articles.headline: Colleges Spending Millions to Deal With Sexual Misconduct Complaints
articles.snippet: Campuses nationwide are relying on lawyers, case workers, advocates and other officials to help negotiate changing ideas and standards of sexual behavior.
articles.abstract: Campuses nationwide are relying on lawyers, case workers, advocates and other officials to help negotiate changing ideas and standards of sexual behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — In a brightly lit classroom here at Harvard, Mia Karvonides was trying to explain to a group of bemused student leaders the difference between a romantic encounter and “unwelcome conduct of a sexual nature,” as the university’s relatively new code of sexual misconduct defines it.

articles.headline: Victory for Unions as Supreme Court, Scalia Gone, Ties 4-4
articles.snippet: When the California teachers case was argued, Justice Antonin Scalia was still alive, and the court appeared ready to hand public unions a setback.
articles.abstract: When the California teachers case was argued, Justice Antonin Scalia was still alive, and the court appeared ready to hand public unions a setback.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court handed organized labor a major victory on Tuesday, deadlocking 4 to 4 in a case that had threatened to cripple the ability of public-sector unions to collect fees from workers who chose not to join and did not want to pay for the unions’ collective bargaining activities.

articles.headline: Starwood Bidder Is a Reclusive Chinese Insurer With Opaque Backing
articles.snippet: Anbang, which is in a bidding war for Starwood Hotels, is controlled by a murky group of interconnected companies and led by a reclusive chairman.
articles.abstract: Anbang, which is in a bidding war for Starwood Hotels, is controlled by a murky group of interconnected companies and led by a reclusive chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: He is often compared in the media to Warren E. Buffett. Like the American billionaire, he is leveraging his control of an insurance company to become one of the biggest names in global finance. Like Mr. Buffett, he looks to be acquiring an immense personal fortune.
